title.narrative: COMMUNITY BASED HEALTH CARE

description.narrative: As of 2019, local authorities and services providers have increased capacity to deliver culturally appropriate and community-based interventions to prevent malnutrition and maternal and child morbidity and mortality, including non-communicable diseases, which contributes to Adolescent Health And Nutrition, Child Health, Child Health (Covid), Community-Based Management Of Acute Malnutrition, Health â€“ General, Immunization, Infant And Young Child Feeding, Maternal And Newborn Health, Prevention Of Stunting And Other Forms Of Malnutrition, Treatment Of Severe Acute Malnutrition, Wash â€“ General, Water, Water (Covid). UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Evaluations, Research And Data, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2019, girls and boys under age 5 in rural, indigenous and afro-descendant communities benefit from culturally appropriate implementation of the national strategy De Cero a Siempre and other relevant policies

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: As of 2019, local authorities and services providers have increased capacity to deliver culturally appropriate and community-basedinterventions to prevent malnutrition and maternal and child morbidity and mortality, including non-communicable diseases

description.narrative: UNICEF Colombia¨s support enabled authorities and other national and local partners responsible for childrens health and early childhood development to have access to guidelines such as the updated for the management of malnutrition and the guide for the management of menstrual hygiene in the school environment, which integrates the gender approach. With regard to strengthening technical capacities, UNICEF Colombia continued its work with communities across educational, family and institutional settings and reached 1,335 people through its Healthy Lifestyles strategy and reached 1,132 individuals through interventions in institutional settings focusing on breastfeeding promotion, while also addressing the challenges of COV19 emergency. | Status:Met | As-of Date:15/01/2021
